Once cool, remove and gently inspect the cinnabar for tempering—if it appears ashen, discard the container. The cinnabar, unbroken, marks the first transformation.

Take one *liang* of *quesha* and half a *jin* of green salt, grind both together into powder, then add a little water to form a paste. Mix this evenly into the previous container’s contents, adjusting moisture to suit. Layer the cinnabar and cover with the medicine as before, without sealing. Place in the ash pit and nurture with three *liang* of fire. Every one *fu* period, add fire five or six times, ensuring no interruption. Nurture for a full seven days, then cool completely. Remove the cinnabar—if it is purple, it is excellent, marking the second transformation. If it remains soft and brittle, grind the cinnabar into powder, add a little green vitriol, and grind evenly. Shape into a pellet using layered paper, secure with thread, and coat thickly with vinegar-ground ink until fully encased. Once dry, place the pellet in the container, cover without sealing, and evenly cover with ash. Nurture with three *liang* of fire for three *fu* periods, then calcine with five *jin* of fire until thoroughly red. When cool, the cinnabar pellet should appear snow-white, marking the third transformation’s completion.

Remove the cinnabar, wash clean to remove saltiness, and dry by baking. Combine with one *ge* of cow’s milk in a bamboo tube with nodes, seal tightly, and suspend in a well for seven days. Retrieve the cinnabar, dry in the sun, and grind into powder. Cook jujubes and form into pills the size of *meng* beans. On a *jiachen* day, purify oneself, burn incense, and take one pill. Increase by one pill each day until the seventh day, then reduce by one pill, continuing this cycle of increase and decrease. After sixty days, effects will manifest, extending to a full year—one’s body will feel light and age will reverse. After three years, the complexion will resemble that of a child, and one’s pace will match that of a galloping horse.

Prolonged ingestion grants longevity, fallen teeth regrow, and if one can further refine the black *ding* into the elixir of immortality, one becomes a transcendent being. For transmutation, no need to remove the fire-toxin—use it directly.

**Bone-Replacing, Form-Preserving, Snow-Descending Elixir**
Meng Yaofu personally attested: I suffered from kidney-wind, lower-body itching, and hemorrhoids for over twenty years. After taking this elixir for a month, the ailments vanished entirely. After a hundred days of ingestion, the Three Corpses were expelled, my stride matched that of a galloping horse, my face and eyes radiated light, my teeth and hair renewed, and my complexion became like that of a maiden. Its divine efficacy defies full description. For transmutation, one pill subdues three *liang* of mercury, instantly forming supreme treasure.

**Elixir Refinement Method**
Take four *liang* of *chen* cinnabar and place it in a silver vessel. Boil with hundred-flower honey for seven full days and nights, then remove. Mix with ten *liang* of pine-resin powder and fine honey to a damp incense-like consistency. Line the bottom of a container, then plant the cinnabar like lotus roots, covering it with the remaining half. Seal the container firmly with Six-One mud. Once dry, place it in an ash bed and nurture with four *liang* of fire for three *fu* periods. When cool, remove the cinnabar, wash it clean, and cover each piece with gold foil. Take half a *jin* of *shizhonghuang*, pound it into fine powder, and spread half in a silver box, pressing firmly. Plant the cinnabar within, then cover with the remaining *shizhonghuang* powder, pressing tightly. Seal the seams with vinegar-mixed red halloysite. Place the box inside a large cauldron, encase it in gold-colored mica powder, and seal completely. Nurture in an ash bed with one *jin* of fire for three seven-day periods. When cool, retrieve it—it will resemble gold. For ingestion, place the elixir in a double-layered silk bag, suspend it in a well one *chi* above the water, and retrieve it after a night. Grind finely into powder, mix with the natural juice of fresh Solomon’s seal in a silver vessel, and simmer into a paste. Form into pills the size of *meng* beans. Take one pill daily on an empty stomach with well-flower water. For transmutation, do not remove the fire-toxin. Place one pill with three *liang* of mercury in a crucible, cover tightly with a dish, seal the edges with four layers of damp paper to prevent black *qi* leakage. Nurture in an ash bed with fire to form treasure. To produce yellow gold, add one *liang* each of realgar and Buddha’s-head blue to the fire-subdued cinnabar, grind into powder, and place in the previous container, sealing it completely. Also encase it in an outer container, nurture in an ash bed with one *jin* of fire for three seven-day periods, then calcine with a *cheng* of fire. When cool, retrieve it—it will be the color of purple gold. The silver box, touched by the elixir’s *qi*, will also turn yellow. Use this elixir to transmute mercury into top-grade yellow gold. Guard this secret closely.

**Crimson-Snow, Flowing-Pearl Elixir Method**
Take one *jin* of translucent, flawless realgar, pound and sift it, then moisten with vinegar. After two days, when dry, moisten again—repeat this ten times. Mix with white alum powder, then cover with alum and seal. After a day and night, dry over gentle fire, gradually increasing the heat but avoiding intensity. After another day and night, apply strong fire until the lower crucible glows like the fire itself, without allowing the fire’s strength to wane even momentarily. Burn thus for three days and nights, then cool for one *fu* period. Open the upper crucible to retrieve the refined essence, grind it finely, and combine with the residue from the lower crucible. Moisten with cooked rice and arrange as before. Refine with gentle and strong fire as previously, until the elixir glows brilliantly red, forming strands like hanging pearls or a spread net. Its radiance dazzles the eyes, startling the heart and spirit of all who see it. For sudden afflictions, near-death, or even apparent death, grind the elixir to the size of three or four sesame seeds, mix with egg yolk, and administer. The patient will raise their head upon ingestion, and recovery follows shortly. Minor malarial fevers are cured instantly. Its divine efficacy defies full description. Alas, the uninitiated hastily use it for gold-making.

**Green Cinnabar Transmutation into Golden Millet Elixir Method**
Cures all wind ailments, extends life, preserves youth, heals myriad diseases, and enables transmutation. Use yellow lead, white clay, and tile powder, mixed with salt and vinegar into a hard mud. Shape wax into spherical molds, coat the spheres with the mud, ensuring no cracks. Dry in shade, then open a small hole and burn away the wax mold. Take fine, lustrous *chen* cinnabar, grind it into powder, roll in stiff paper, and pour into the sphere. Seal the hole with earthworm mud and let dry. Forge an iron ring to match the sphere’s shape, embed the sphere within, and place it in a cauldron, securing it so the top and bottom remain unobstructed. Pour lead-niter solution into the cauldron to a depth of two *cun*, then nurture with chaff fire, ensuring it does not cool. Wait until the lead melts. Maintain this for one hundred twenty days, increasing the fire, then remove and calcine on the ground. When cool, retrieve the elixir—it will resemble green-purple snail shells. Discard the black, unusable portions. Take half the elixir, place it in a green bamboo tube, seal it, and steam with milk five times, changing the milk thrice. The milk skin can treat wild goiter. Retrieve the elixir and bury it in a pit for three nights. Grind it into fine powder, mix with millet porridge, and form into millet-sized pills. Those aged forty take one pill, fifty take two, sixty take three—do not exceed this dosage. It cures all wind ailments and extends life while preserving youth. Place the remaining fine elixir powder in a crucible, layer it with one *liang* of fine alum powder above and below, and seal completely.

When the elixir is dry, place it in ashes to nurture for forty-nine days, then calcine with great fire. Once cool, open the vessel—all will have transformed into golden millet grains. Take one *sheng* of mouse-tail-shaped cinnabar and form it into a stick, then take three *liang* of *shushi* (ochre) and half a portion of true *geng* (lead). First melt the *geng* into liquid in a crucible, then add three or four grains of golden millet, which will transmute into true Western metal. The perforated ball must be placed with its hole facing upward inside the lead crucible, then nurtured with fire below.

**Method for Refining *Geng* Powder:**
Take ten *liang* of fine *geng* and fifty *liang* of mercury, place them in a porcelain jar, and keep warm with fire. Heat the *geng* until red-hot, then immerse it in mercury, stirring with a willow twig until the *geng* dissolves completely. Take three *jin* of *guan* flower (alum) and grind it finely with gold mud, then place it in a large cauldron and level it. Cover tightly with a basin, seal all around with mud to ensure airtightness, and calcine slowly until the mercury sublimes onto the basin—continue until the mercury is fully volatilized. Next, rinse with water to remove the *guan* flavor completely, then dry the refined *geng* powder in the sun. Grind it finely and incorporate it into the elixir.

Take eight *liang* of cockscomb-shaped realgar, eight *liang* of lamellar orpiment, four *liang* of halite, ten *liang* of gold powder, and five *liang* of golden millet. Grind these five ingredients into a fine powder. Transfer them to a new crucible, following the previous method, and evenly coat the interior with ink ground from musk and rice vinegar. Place the elixir inside and heat with gentle and strong fire alternately until the elixir liquefies. Add four *liang* of finely ground nitre powder to the crucible, filling it tightly with thick paste. Seal the opening with paper, cover with a lid, and ensure it is airtight and dry. As before, place it in the crucible, seal it tightly, and pour molten lead over the vessel to a depth of two *cun*. Choose an auspicious day and begin firing at midnight during the *zi* hour, starting with six *liang* of fuel and increasing by one *liang* each day until sixty days are complete. Once cool, chisel open the vessel, remove the lead, and retrieve the crucible—the elixir will have turned the color of purple gold. Grind one *fen* of it finely in a mortar; it can transmute one *jin* of mercury into gold instantly. This is not something ordinary people can obtain—it is a secret transmission from the immortals. If used to aid the Dao, one must know contentment.

**Coating *Geng*:**
Grind one *liang* of green vitriol, five *qian* of white alum, three *qian* of salt, and eight *qian* of saltpeter into a fine powder. Knead sweet clay into a trough, shape the *geng* into hairpins, dip them in water, then roll them in the powder mixture. Place them in the trough and heat over fire. Remove and dip in a water basin—repeat this process five times to achieve a superior, jewel-like color.

**Tai Xu Ling Sha Dan (Elixir of Supreme Void Numinous Cinnabar)**
The *Dongxuan Ji* states: "Refine the Nine Cycles of Golden Liquid Dragon-Tiger Great Elixir." Ge Xianweng of the *Baopuzi* said: "The method for the Supreme Clarity Divine Elixir originates from the Primordial Lord, who was the teacher of Laozi and the greatest of celestial deities. He harmonizes yin and yang, commands wind and rain, rides clouds and dragons, and all the immortals of heaven are subject to him. Even my own study of the Dao has been achieved through the ingestion of this elixir. The superior adept who obtains it becomes an official of heaven; the middling adept dwells in the mountains; the lesser adept enjoys longevity in the world. Foolish people do not believe in it, dismissing it as empty words. From morning to night, they seek only the means of death, never pursuing life—how could heaven force life upon them? Most people crave only fine food, beautiful clothes, music, sensual pleasures, wealth, and honor. Indulging their passions and desires, they treat life lightly, hastening their demise. Take care not to speak of the golden elixir to such people, lest they mock the Dao and slander the truth. Do not transmit the elixir scriptures to those who are not of noble character; only to those of sincere faith may they be passed on."

He further instructed his disciples: "According to the *Huangdi Jiuding Shendan Jing*, the Yellow Emperor ascended as an immortal by ingesting it. Breathing exercises and herbal medicines can only prolong life and cure illness—they cannot prevent death. If one wholeheartedly consumes the divine elixir, one’s lifespan becomes boundless, enduring as long as heaven and earth. One may ride clouds and dragons to ascend to the Great Clarity—all due to this divine elixir. Yixuanzi warns: This Dao is of utmost importance and must be transmitted only to the worthy. Even if someone amasses gold like mountains, do not speak of this to them. Those without immortal bones must also not be allowed to know of it. If those who do not believe in the Dao learn of it, they will not only slander the divine elixir but also prevent its successful refinement. Only those with immortal bones and sincere faith in the elixir Dao may, after the elixir is completed, ascend as immortals with their entire households. Yet people today do not believe in the divine elixir, preferring instead to trust in herbal medicines. But herbs, once buried, decay—how can they grant longevity when ingested? Cinnabar is the substance of immortality; when refined and consumed, how could it not extend life? The masses of the world are foolish and ignorant, craving only wealth and indulging their desires, seeking nothing but death. How could they know that those who cultivate the truth dwell in the world yet transcend it, restraining themselves and pledging their hearts to the pursuit of attainment? If gentlemen who savor the Dao have aspirations in this regard, to together propagate the mystery of the Way—is this not wonderful?"

**Sun Zhenren’s Elixir Scripture: Chapter on the Five Metals and Eight Minerals**
**Five Metals:** Cinnabar, mercury, realgar, orpiment, sulfur.
**Eight Minerals:** Azurite, malachite, chalcanthite, arsenic, borax, white alum, white vitriol, nitre.

The five metals die when encountering mercury; the eight minerals perish when meeting nitre. Cinnabar, realgar, and orpiment are called "sentient substances," each with distinct uses. *Sengxi* yellow, *shiting* fat, and sweet sulfur are three substances with different names but the same nature. When refined with fire, they excel at transmuting silver into red mercury, forming the great treasure.

**Section on Cinnabar (from the Five Metals)**
Cinnabar is both water and fire. Take eight taels of fine, genuine cinnabar and place it in a smooth, new porcelain vessel. Pack the vessel’s rim with damp earth to prevent smoke from escaping. Take eight taels of mercury and five *haima* (sea horses), grind them to powder, and mix evenly with the cinnabar and mercury. Next, take fine *chige* (red grass) stalks, half-dried, burn them to ash, and place the ash in an earthen jar. Pour water over it to leach the liquid, then use a cast-iron cauldron with a frost-like patina on its base. Line the bottom and cover the top of the porcelain vessel with this, and heat it with gentle and strong fire until the vessel gradually warms. Then apply intense fire to calcine it, melt it into liquid, and remove it to form white cinnabar. Place it in a tripod over a furnace, following the methods in the previous elixir scriptures: weigh the proportions precisely, arrange them according to yin-yang positions, and cycle them in accordance with the *Can Tong Qi* (Token for the Agreement of the Three). Align with the four seasons, eight solar terms, twenty-four qi phases, seventy-two pentads, and the celestial patterns of years, months, days, and hours—without the slightest error. Nurture it gently, like a hen brooding eggs, for one hundred twenty days. Remove it, grind it into fine powder, and form pills with *chuanbanxia* (pinellia) juice, each the size of a millet grain. Consuming one pill extends life by three hundred years; ten pills, three thousand years. Its power transforms the intestines, and it is called *Shenfu Baixue Dan* (Divine Talisman White Snow Elixir), excelling at transmuting blood into milk. If one encounters a perfected being who points to the true qi of the Mysterious Female and the One, and can stabilize the embryo and preserve the spirit, ascension is certain within three years. The elixir’s inner workings follow the rhythms of heaven and earth, aligning with the four seasons—this is the principle of the first transformation. With this, all silver, gold, and minerals from mountains and marshes can be instantly transmuted into supreme treasures. If the elixir is used to refine mercury, it will subdue its volatility and transmute it into treasure. Stirring it fifty or sixty times in one place can turn base gold into the finest treasure. This elixir is called *Shenfu Baixue* (Divine Talisman White Snow) among the great elixirs. The superior person values life over wealth; the inferior, wealth over life. This elixir must not be transmitted to the unworthy.

**Section on Realgar (from the Five Metals)**
Realgar originates from Wudu Mountain, embodying the qi of metal and wood. Take fine, deep red realgar resembling a rooster’s comb, and grind it to a fine powder. Use high-quality *guming* (bright) green vitriol, *zijin* (purple gold), *longya* (dragon sprouts), and the frost-like stalks of *chige* (red grass, also called *chige*). Layer these seven substances in a new porcelain jar, placing the elixir inside. Cover it and heat with gentle and strong fire, gradually increasing the intensity. Then apply intense fire until it sweats, remove the top, and place it on stone for three days until it turns gold-red. Return it to the porcelain jar and nurture it with chaff fire for nine days. Remove it, melt mountain silver into liquid gold, and use the elixir to transmute it—it will instantly become treasure, with a ten-thousand-fold success rate.

Orpiment also comes from Wudu Mountain, embodying the qi of metal and wood. Take fine, golden orpiment resembling *yueye* (moon leaves), grind it to a fine powder, and combine it with high-quality bright green vitriol, *yimucao* (motherwort), *yiwushou* (black nightshade), and *longyacao* (dragon sprouts). Burn these to ash, leach the liquid, and boil it into a frost-like paste. Layer it in a new porcelain jar, place the elixir inside, cover it, and heat with gentle and strong fire, gradually increasing the intensity. Then apply intense fire to calcine it until the smoke ceases and it melts into liquid. This can transmute fine mountain silver into supreme treasure.

**Section on Sulfur (from the Five Metals)**
For sulfur, use sweet sulfur, *sengxi* yellow, or *shiting* fat—three substances with different names but the same nature. Use fine, bright, crystalline green vitriol, or burn *chige* (red grass) to ash, leach the liquid, and boil it into frost. Layer it in a new porcelain jar, place the elixir inside, cover it, and heat with gentle and strong fire, gradually increasing the intensity. Then apply intense fire to destroy it until the smoke ceases and it melts into liquid. This can transmute silver into treasure.

**Section on White Superior Yellow (from the Five Metals)**
White Superior Yellow originates from the peaks of Shangdang Mountain, resembling red powder in color. Next, use fine cinnabar, transparent as crystal—the foremost among the five metals. Take *chige* (red grass) ash, *zijin* (purple gold), *longya* (dragon sprouts), and *huangqin* (skullcap), burn them to ash, leach the liquid, and boil it into frost. Layer it in a new porcelain jar, place the elixir inside, cover it, and heat with gentle and strong fire, gradually increasing the intensity. Then apply intense fire to calcine it until the smoke ceases and it melts into liquid. This can transmute raw iron and copper into treasure, and refine mercury into treasure as well.

Layer it in a new porcelain jar, place the medicine inside, cover it, and heat with gentle and strong fire, gradually increasing the intensity. Apply intense fire to calcine it until the smoke ceases and it melts into liquid, which can transmute copper and iron into treasure.

Layer it in a new porcelain jar, place the medicine inside, cover it, and heat with gentle and strong fire, gradually increasing the intensity until the smoke ceases and it melts into liquid. Layer it in a new porcelain jar, place the medicine inside, cover it, and heat with fire, gradually increasing the intensity before applying intense fire until the smoke ceases and it melts into liquid. Use only the finest, pure, and crystalline sal ammoniac. Layer it in a new porcelain jar, place the medicine inside, cover it, and heat with gentle and strong fire, gradually increasing the intensity until the smoke ceases and it melts into liquid. Use only the finest, naturally hardened, luminous salt. Then grind *yimucao* (motherwort) into fine powder, layer it in a new porcelain jar, place the medicine inside, cover it, and heat with gentle and strong fire, gradually increasing the intensity until the smoke ceases and it melts into liquid. Layer it in a new porcelain jar, place the medicine inside, cover it, and heat with gentle and strong fire, gradually increasing the intensity until the smoke ceases and it melts into liquid. **Methods for Subduing the Five Metals**
**Subduing Cinnabar (Primary Method)**
*Method for Subduing Cinnabar with Herbs (from the* Purple Empyrean Elixir Classic *of Master Ge)*
Take cinnabar in lumps, regardless of quantity, wrap it in sheep’s tripe grass, collect and dry it, also without fixed amount. Grind it thoroughly into powder. In a porcelain container, first place half the powder, then arrange the cinnabar in the center, and cover it with the remaining powder, packing it tightly. Calcine it with three to five catties of charcoal fire until evenly heated, then use it.

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar into Silver**
Two taels of alum powder, one qian of saltpeter powder, a small amount of *jinchi* (golden wings), and one tael of cinnabar. Grind these ingredients into powder. First melt one and a half taels of *pengsha* (borax) in a spoon until half-cooked, then grind it into powder before adding the other medicinal powders. Grind them together, place in a tea bowl, and simmer over low heat, then grind again into powder. Coat each piece of cinnabar by holding it in the mouth, then apply the medicinal powder. Take one and a half taels of mountain-refined silver, hammer it into two round sheets. Place one sheet at the bottom of a porcelain container, arrange the cinnabar pieces, and scatter silver bits the size of barley grains among them. Cover with the other sheet, fill the gaps with silver, and seal tightly with Six-One Mud. Once dry, calcine first with gentle fire, then with strong fire until red-hot. Cool, then place in the Flower Pool to refine into treasure.

**Method for Subduing White Cinnabar**
Equal parts of *jvnücao* (maiden grass), *gansui* (kan-sui), *xusuizi* (caper spurge), and *woju* (lettuce). Grind them into powder, place one qian of the herbal powder in a container, then arrange the cinnabar, cover it with the remaining powder, seal tightly, and heat with gentle and strong fire for one *fu* period.

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar**
Five taels of silver powder, five taels of fine cinnabar, and eight gold leaves. In a porcelain container, first place four gold leaves, then a layer of silver powder, then arrange the cinnabar in the center. Alternate layers of silver powder and cinnabar until all are used, then fill the gaps with lead powder and oyster shell powder, seal tightly, and dry. Cover the top, heat with four taels of fire, and nurture for two seven-day periods.

**Method for Refining Cinnabar with Herbs**
*Dìdǎn* grass, *zhāngliǔ*, *dàjǐ* (kan-sui), *sháoyào* (peony), *jiǎndāo* grass, and *mǎchǐ* grass. Take equal parts of the fresh herbs listed above, pound them into a paste, place the cinnabar in the center, and seal tightly. Once dry, calcine with two to three catties of charcoal fire until it melts into liquid.

**Herbal Method for Subduing Cinnabar**
Remove the roots of *mǎchǐ* (purslane) and *wǔfāng* grass. Place three taels of cinnabar in a porcelain container: first lay a layer of herbs, then arrange the cinnabar, and cover with another layer of herbs. Seal tightly and calcine with fire.

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar**
One tael of cinnabar and one tael of white alum. First spread half of the alum in a crucible and melt it into liquid, then place the cinnabar, and cover with the remaining alum. Arrange all layers, then calcine with fire until thoroughly red.

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar into Metal (Jīn)**
Half a catty of fine *shénjǐn* cinnabar, half a tael each of yellow alum, *shídǎn* (chalcanthite), *jīguān* realgar, and *pào shā* (calcined cinnabar). Grind all into powder, mix with rice vinegar into a paste, and boil in a porcelain pot until slightly bubbling—this suffices. Boil for ten days or more; if the cinnabar remains unchanged, it is ready. If not, continue boiling until subdued by fire. Form into glutinous rice-sized pills. For every tael of mercury, place one pill in a vessel, nurture with four taels of fire for one tea period, and it will become a treasure.

**Method for Refining and Subduing Cinnabar into Supreme Treasure Medicine**
Take one tael of fine cinnabar, the size of dice, wrap it in two layers of gold foil, and place it in a porcelain container. Line the bottom and cover the top with *jiǔzhuǎn* subdued-fire refined salt as a protective layer, filling and pressing firmly. Evenly cover with oyster shell powder, seal properly, and first nurture with one tael of fire from the *chén* hour (7–9 AM) to the *wǔ* hour (11 AM–1 PM), then increase the fire to three catties until red-hot. Allow to cool, open the container, remove the oyster shell first, then retrieve the cinnabar—now subdued by fire. If the cinnabar retains its original color, it is ready as a protective layer, purged of fire toxins, and suitable for consumption. Form into sesame-sized pills with honey; ingestion prolongs life. If reused in a container, wrap the cinnabar in gold or silver foil, nurture with fire for twenty-one days, and it will fully become treasure—gold foil yields metal (jīn), silver foil yields silver.

**Nine-Turn Method for Subduing Mercury with Cinnabar**
Take five taels of fine cinnabar and gather moss from the shady side of an old wall, drying and grinding it into powder. Grind the cinnabar into powder, place it in an oil-permeable container, lining the bottom and covering the top with moss powder. Mix earthworm castings and salt into a paste, seal the container with a layer one finger thick, and let dry. Place it on a *bó* (clay support), calcine with one catty of fire until red-hot. Once cool, remove and break into lumps—its color will be purplish-red. Grind into powder again and calcine as before; its color will deepen. Without pressing, it will later transform into a purplish-red hue, lustrous as a mirror reflecting people. Repeat the process nine times, and it becomes suitable for consumption, prolonging life—this is the *jiǔzhuǎn* cinnabar protective layer.

**Master Dīng’s Precious Crucible Method for Subduing Cinnabar**
Five taels of fine cinnabar, ground into powder. One tael of *jiēzhōu* rock salt powder and two taels of *Qín* soil from outside the east gate of Fengxiang, both ground into powder. Separately, use clay to form a crucible base, shaping it like a *gān* crucible, ensuring it is smooth. Pound and extract the natural juice from the stems and leaves of purple-stemmed lettuce, mix it with the previously prepared salt powder and *Qín* soil, stirring until even and of proper consistency. Coat the crucible base with this mixture to form a *gān* crucible, about five *fēn* thick. If not firm enough, add paper and pound until well-mixed, then reshape. Remove the base, dry thoroughly over a gentle fire, fill the crucible’s mouth with cinnabar, and tightly pack a bundle of purple-stemmed lettuce stems to seal it, preventing gas escape. Leave about half the space above, tie the bundle securely with thread, and place the crucible on a *bó* with a small central depression to hold it steady. Surround with fire and calcine until thoroughly red-hot, then cease when smoke dissipates. Remove from fire, let cool, and the cinnabar will resemble amber in color and luster, luminous enough to reflect people—suitable for consumption and life extension. To refine further into a protective layer, repeat the process three to five times; each turn enhances its brilliance, weight, and spiritual efficacy, the details of which cannot be fully described. It subdues all mineral medicines, transforming them as desired. Only the *Three Yellows* (sulfur, realgar, orpiment) resist alteration; calcining requires at least two catties of fire. This method was once presented to Commander Wang of the Gold and Feather Guard.

**Master Sūn’s Alchemical Classic: Various Methods for Subduing Cinnabar**

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar with Stone Yellow**
Four taels of cinnabar and one catty of *shímiáo* (stone sprouts). Grind both into fine powder, place in a cinnabar or porcelain container to about half its capacity, and press firmly. Insert a wooden mold, pack *shíhuáng* (stone yellow) around it, then remove the mold. Lightly moisten the cinnabar with water and roll it in borax. Fill the cavity with *shízhōnghuáng* (stone-center yellow), cover with *shíhuáng*, seal tightly, and let dry. Bury in a one- to two-*chǐ* deep pit, fill with dry horse manure, and burn for two seven-day periods, replenishing the manure to maintain uninterrupted fire. After the full duration, apply three catties of fire on top until fully calcined. Once cool, retrieve it—its color will be peach-blossom red, melting into a treasure for any use.

**Method for Subduing Fire with Cinnabar**
Use cinnabar in nuggets, any quantity. First, grind purple-skinned garlic into a paste and evenly coat the inside of a new *gān* crucible to a thickness of about one finger. Line the bottom with *gǒuqǐ* (goji) leaves, mix the cinnabar with garlic paste, place it in the crucible, cover with another layer of *gǒuqǐ* leaves, and press firmly with garlic paste. Seal the mouth with a tile, coat with red clay, and reinforce with paper-fiber mortar to a uniform thickness of one finger.

Allow to dry in the shade, then place in an ash pit and nurture with civil and martial fire for one *fu* period. Apply ten catties of fire until fully calcined. Once cool, retrieve and heat the cinnabar over fire until red, then quench in saltwater until the desired color is achieved—this subdues the fire. If the cinnabar crumbles upon biting, reseal as before and apply five catties of fire to complete the process.

**Method for Subduing White Cinnabar**
Boil two taels of Sichuan pepper in one *sheng* of water until reduced to half. Cool the liquid. Grind one tael of silver foil into powder, combine with four *qian* of mercury, and pound with the pepper into a paste. Strain through raw silk to extract the mercury paste. Adjust the size and quantity of cinnabar nuggets to form cakes of one tael each, then chew thoroughly in the mouth. Use seven cloves to assess the cinnabar in the mouth, then sandwich it between two mercury paste cakes, ensuring even thickness. Mix equal parts of cassia bark, white aconite, *wasong* (moss on tiles), Sichuan pepper, and lotus leaves into a powder. Sprinkle half into a container to form a nest for the cinnabar cakes. For ingestion, apply a layer of yellow lead (*huangdan*) about one *qian* thick, place the cinnabar on top, and cover with another *qian* of yellow lead. Fill the container with the remaining powder, seal the seams with red halloysite mixed with vinegar, and reinforce with mortar to a uniform thickness. Calcine with half a *chen* of charcoal fire to produce white cinnabar (omit the yellow lead if not needed).

**Method for Boiling Cinnabar into a Treasure**
Take five leaves of *jingfeng* grass, one tael each of sour nuggets and cinnabar. Place each in a silk bag, tie securely, and dip halfway in rice vinegar. Place in an iron vessel with half a *jin* of rice vinegar, two *sheng* of water, and two taels of *mu furong* (hibiscus) branches and leaves. Boil for one *fu* period over a slow fire. Remove, drain, and select the cinnabar, discarding the rest.

**Another Method for Refining Cinnabar**
Melt three taels of cinnabar in a crucible until liquefied, using a slow fire. Once fully molten and boiling, pour onto the ground, collect the cinnabar, and return it to a *gan* crucible. Heat until it smokes and liquefies again, then pour into a bran trough to form silver.

**Zhang Zihou’s *Grass-Seeing Treasure Elixir* Method**
**First Boiling Method**
Grind two taels each of *yangti* root, *diding*, *you* grass, *didancao*, and *yimucao* into coarse powder. Use one *dou* and five *sheng* of river water to boil eight taels of bright cinnabar (avoid finely crushed or impure pieces) with the herbs in a silver or stone vessel, suspended above the liquid. Boil for one *fu* period, maintaining a gentle simmer like fish eyes. Replenish water as needed, then rinse the cinnabar with river water after boiling.

**Second Calcining Method and Fire Nurturing**
Grind two taels each of *songluo*, *diyu*, *baihuacai*, and *yindijue* into powder. Mix with raw honey to a consistency like moist incense. Spread one-third of the mixture on the bottom of a container, arrange the cinnabar like lotus seeds without touching, and cover with another layer of the mixture. Repeat until all cinnabar and powder are used, pressing firmly on top. Seal the seams with red halloysite mixed with vinegar, then coat the entire vessel with *liuyi* mud to a thickness of one finger. Allow to dry in the shade, ensuring no cracks; if any appear, patch with mud. Cover with a three-finger-thick layer of vinegar-mixed grass ash, pressing firmly. Place five catties of charcoal beneath, ignite from the top, and calcine until half is consumed. Add another five catties, then another five catties once half is consumed again. When nearly half remains, cover with a basin overnight. Retrieve the cinnabar, place in a clean sand container, seal the seams with red halloysite, and set in a small earthen jar. Elevate with a three-legged iron stand, bury in paper-money ash to a depth of four fingers above the container. At the *zi* and *wu* hours, add four taels of mature fire. Nurture for two seven-day periods, then apply a strong fire to fully calcine without losing the true subdued fire. For ingestion, grind into fine powder, form into *tongzi*-sized pills with pinellia paste, and take on an empty stomach with warm water. For transmutation or storage, boil three times, replacing the herbs each time, and follow the previous fire-nurturing method. For transmutation, form into pills with paper mulberry juice—ten pills per tael, each pill transmuting one tael of copper into treasure. For storage, mix three *qian* of silver and seven *qian* of mercury, grind into cinnabar, and divide into ten pills. Use eight taels of previously calcined cinnabar as a base powder, spreading half on the bottom and half on top. Follow the initial cinnabar-nurturing method: first nurture for twenty-one days, then reduce by one day each time until the fire is vigorous, nurturing for only one *fu* period to form the supreme treasure—this is the *Elixir of Longevity*.

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar with Half-Tael Coins (from *Xuanzhenzi’s Concordance Records*)**
Take any quantity of half-tael coins, heat each until thoroughly red, then quench in vinegar. Coat the coins with sulfur powder after wetting with warm water, place in a container, and cover with more sulfur powder. Seal, allow to dry, then cover the top. Nurture with four taels of fire for three days, then calcine until fully red. Cool, grind finely, and use to subdue cinnabar following the previous fire-nurturing method. Store as an elixir. For subdued cinnabar, add raw cinnabar—more is better, especially if using high-quality mother cinnabar.

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar**
Line a container with bamboo and seal. Calcine with a strong fire until thoroughly red, then cool and retrieve. Do not nurture. Use two taels of arsenic trioxide, half a tael of *fen shuang* (calomel), one tael of *hanshuishi* (calcium sulfate), one tael of *jin fan* (alum), and one *fen* of saltpeter.

Grind the above ingredients to a fine powder and place in a small jar, separating them with black paper. Then transfer to a larger jar, filling the surrounding space with lime. Repeat this process without limit until no sound is heard, then gradually withdraw the fire. Once cooled, retrieve a jadelike mass. For each use, take a piece the size of a soapberry, add to one tael of *mao* (lead?), stir with a willow twig, and pour out to form a treasure.

**Method for Subduing Cinnabar with Licorice**
Take eight taels of firm, solid licorice and grind to a fine powder, along with two and a half taels of cinnabar, also finely ground. Spread a thin layer of licorice powder—about three *fen* thick—in a porcelain container, then add a layer of cinnabar powder. Alternate layers of licorice and cinnabar, repeating until all the cinnabar is used, with a final top layer of licorice powder about three to five *fen* thick. Seal the container all around with paper and mud, secure it with an iron wire mesh, and seal again with paper and mud to resemble a ball. Dig a wide pit in the ground, surround the container with embers, and cover the embers with crushed husks. Ignite with approximately one *chen* of charcoal, firing until thoroughly red, then cease at the desired time. Remove the container—ensuring nothing burns inside—and reseal it as before. Surround it again with embers and husks, firing once more in the same manner. Once cooled, the cinnabar will be subdued. Store it in a crucible container and submerge in a well to dispel fire toxins. After one *fu* period, grind the cinnabar finely, mix with glutinous rice porridge, and form into pills the size of peas. Take one pill daily. If used for transmutation, do not dispel fire toxins; instead, store it in an elixir vessel and refine it through nine cycles for divine efficacy.

**Purple Empyrean Scripture’s Method for Subduing Mercury**
*Huainan King’s Cinnabar Seed Method for Subduing Mercury*
Gather *dijin* in spring, lotus leaves and rattan in autumn, *liushouzi* and *wufangcao* in autumn. Take equal parts of the above, pound while moist into a paste, then mix with one *liang* of mercury. Fire with one to two *jin* of fuel until red-hot, then cool and remove the vessel. Take three *liang* of frost-white *yimucao*, blend with water, and place the cinnabar within. Fire with three to five *jin* of fuel, and it becomes a treasure.

**Three Grades of Minor Return Elixir: Method for Restraining Mercury**
*Xuanhu*, reed catkins, and bright cinnabar mercury—five *liang* each. Grind the above together, place in a crucible, and pack tightly with halite. Moisten the mouth to level it, then use an iron pick to pierce five to seven holes the size of chopsticks. Insert a perforated tile over the crucible’s mouth, sinking it about one *cun* deep. Center a hole in the tile and seat it atop a flat-bottomed water vessel, ensuring all seams are sealed. Once dry, surround it with charcoal, starting with half a *jin* and increasing to three *jin*. After one *fu* period, when the crucible glows the same color as the fire, the mercury will descend entirely into the small vessel—five *liang* each. No refining is lost, and both mercury and medicine turn thoroughly red.

Take this medicine again, then take fifteen *liang* of sal ammoniac, first melt it to an oily consistency, stir until clear, and grind to powder. Wrap in alum paper, then take ten parts of calcined lead powder and place it in a tripod as an outer vessel. Inside, use one *jin* of purple fluorite powder, center a golden *niaozi*, and cover it above and below with purple fluorite powder. Top with calcined lead, packing tightly. Gradually expel all yin qi until dry. Seal the tripod with its lid, then reinforce the seal. Once thoroughly dry, place it in the furnace with one *jin* of fire, maintaining it for sixty days without interruption. If the fire wanes, extend by five days. This is called *Purple Gold Sand*. Then take one *liang*, grind to powder, and place ten *liang* of mercury in a cauldron. Cover with the powdered medicine for three days, then seal tightly with an iron lid, embedding its edges. Apply sixty *liang* of fire above and four *liang* below. After three *fu* periods, it naturally forms a sheet of silver, ready for use.

Again, grind all the previous medicine into powder. Take half a *jin* of sal ammoniac, return it to the vessel, and cover as before. Seal and dry, then fire for sixty days—this is called *Purple Spirit Sand*. As before, take one *liang* of the medicine, grind to powder, and cover one *jin* of mercury. Seal firmly, and within a day it transforms into a cauldron of silver.

Grind all into powder again, mix with half a *jin* of cinnabar, and stir into sand. Follow the previous method, nurturing it for sixty days—this is called the *Minor Return Elixir*. One *liang* makes five hundred pills; each pill, when applied to one *er* of dry mercury, instantly becomes silver.

**Another Method for Restraining Mercury**
Heat one *liang* of mercury intensely, then drop in one pill of the medicine. The pill darts across the mercury’s surface in all directions, then sinks. The mercury dries instantly. Remove the pill, pour the mercury into a trough, and once cooled, it becomes silver, ready for use.

Form this medicine into pills and consume them to attain longevity, sharing the lifespan of heaven and earth. Carrying one pill of this elixir into the wilderness causes all beasts to submit; birds become phoenixes, dogs become dragons. Those who consume it achieve immortality—this is the *Minor Return Elixir*, transcending great calamities and ranking first among immortals’ arts.

*Song:*
If white gold is achieved, the world may be delivered;
If white gold fails, one’s efforts are in vain.
Those who encounter this method
Are destined by past lives to have immortal affinity,
Their names recorded in the celestial registers.
Without the ladder to immortality,
One would never meet this elixir to consume.

**Method for Subduing Mercury with Green Cloth**
Spread *dijin* to form a thatched mat. Use only lotus flowers, water chestnut leaves, pagoda tree pods, *yuanzhi*, and gallnuts—never let women know when compounding.

Take the following in equal parts: *dijin*, *mao’er yancao*, lotus flowers, lotus leaves, pagoda tree pods, *yuanzhi*, and gallnuts—one *liang* each—and grind to powder. First line the bottom of a crucible with *dijin*, then spread *mao’er yancao* powder (quantity as needed). Place mercury inside, then cover completely with lotus flowers, lotus leaves, pagoda tree pods, gallnuts, and *yuanzhi*. Seal the crucible’s mouth with a tile, then seal the exterior with two *cun* of mud. Dry in the shade, then fire with five *jin* of charcoal. Dispel fire toxins overnight. The next day, break the crucible to find the mercury solidified into lumps, ready for use.

**Method for Nurturing Green-Gold Heads into Silver with a Herb Vessel**
Eight *qian* of mercury, three *qian* of sulfur, one *qian* of alum, three *qian* of *mu*. Grind to powder.

First, slowly stir-fry mercury, sulfur, and alum over low fire to form sand. Then take equal parts of *baiyou*, *baiqian*, Sichuan pepper, Sichuan aconite, *xixin*, and purslane, grind to fine powder, and pound into a paste. Line the inside of a crucible with this paste, adhering it to the walls. Place the green-gold sand inside, then cover with *shanze* powder. Seal with a tile, then coat the exterior with *liuyi* mud one finger thick. Dry in the shade, patching cracks as they form. Once dry, place in a large earthenware or iron pot atop a trivet. Set the medicine ball inside, then nurture the top with *jinsu* fire, maintaining four *liang* of charcoal to keep it warm. The base should remain consistently warm—reduce if too hot, add if too cool. Nurture thus for three days until firm, then apply strong fire. Once cooled, remove the ball and shake it; if it rattles, the substance is complete.

**Sun the Perfected’s Scripture’s Herb Method for Subduing Mercury**
Lotus leaves and *lutí*. First soak sulfur in water overnight, then remove and dry in the shade. Grind to powder, mix with mercury in a pan, and stir-fry to form sand. Wrap in paper and bury in the earth for one *liang* period. When unearthed, it has already become sand.

**Additional Methods**

**Method One**
Castor leaves, white oxalis with three corners, *hanlian* (eclipta), *dìdīng* (viola), *jinlian* (potentilla), *xùtiān* (cynanchum), and *yúxīngcǎo* (houttuynia)—or use purslane. Grind these to a fine powder, except for purslane, which should be mashed. Then grind with mercury in a mortar, cover with the five herbs, and nurture over ash fire until faint smoke rises. Before completion, pour into water to soften the sand, then remove and wrap in paper. For every *liang* of purslane and mercury, the result will be a pellet the size of a bullet.

**Method Two**
*Dàotuíténg* (inverted vine, *Datura* flower) and *tiěchángcǎo* (iron-intestine grass). Dry these two ingredients in the shade, grind to powder, and mix with one cup of water in an iron pan. Simmer over gentle and strong fire until dry, then stir-fry until the herbs turn to ash. Pour the already-formed mercury sand into the palm and roll into a single lump.

**Method for Subduing Mercury into Western Sand**
One *liang* of mercury, one *qián* of *dǎnfán* (chalcanthite), two *qián* of high-quality *qīngfán* (melanterite), and a soybean-sized piece of *hūshā* (sal ammoniac). Grind these together into a fine powder, add two *qián* of *lóngdǎncǎo* (gentian) powder, and mix thoroughly. Stew with one cup of sour *zǎo* (jujube) juice in an iron pan for the duration of two meals, until dry. Avoid vigorous boiling; let the edges simmer gently for two hours. Lift with a bamboo stick—when it resembles silk floss, remove and wrap the residue in paper. If the sand is incomplete, continue stewing as before. Cover with a bowl and store overnight; by the next day, it will turn red. The pan must be new and unused for best results; avoid grease.

**Sealing and Refining Method**
*Lúgānshí* (calamine) with star-like patterns, *dàizhěshí* (hematite), and alum in equal parts. Grind these three into a fine powder and place in a crucible. Position the mercury sand in the center and cover it completely with the powder. Then mix *chìshízhī* (red halloysite) and clam powder with water into a stiff paste to seal the crucible’s mouth, ensuring it is thoroughly airtight. Refine with one *jīn* of charcoal fire. When the blue smoke nearly dissipates, remove, let cool, and open to reveal the treasure.

**Another Method**
Five *liǎng* of mercury, five *liǎng* of *dǎnfán*, five *liǎng* of *qīngfán*, and three and a half *liǎng* of white alum. Grind these into a fine powder. Place the mercury in an iron pan and cover it with the three alum powders. Apply gentle and strong fire on a wind furnace, adding one large bowl of *zǎo* juice. Warm the juice first, then pour it into the pan one cup at a time. To produce *gēng* sand, add five *liǎng* of *lóngdǎncǎo* powder to the alums before stewing. Alternatively, decoct *lóngdǎncǎo* separately into a thick juice, pour into the pan, and stew with the *zǎo* juice to form *gēng* sand. During stewing, maintain a gentle simmer; avoid vigorous boiling at the edges to prevent mercury from spilling. When the edges are dry, remove and let cool. Gently brush aside the alum, pour the sand into a crucible, wash it clean, and let it sit overnight before it turns red. Only then is it ready for the sealing process.

**Method for Subduing Mercury into Western Sand**
Three *qián* of *mǔ* (mother metal), hammered into foil and cut into pieces. Seven *qián* of mercury, ground with pepper decoction as in the *gǎnqì* method. Then use the following herbs—*máojuǎn* (reed roll), *xiāngtiānquè fěn* (unknown powder), and *wúmíngyì* (pyrolusite)—ground into fine powder, mixed with honey into a paste, and wrapped in cloth. Fry in four *liǎng* of hempseed oil, adding forty-nine *guāzǐ* (melon seeds) one by one until they turn brown. Continue until two-thirds of the oil remains. Clean with a toothbrush to remove excess oil, then store in a sealed container.

**Method for the Mercury-Transforming Bone Elixir**
*Bìlì* (fig vine), *xiàkūcǎo* (prunella), *yúxīngcǎo* (houttuynia), white *hànlián* (eclipta), and *mùmántóu* (Chinese gall). Grind these into fine powder, refine with honey, and form into pills. Press a hollow in the center of each pill, place mercury inside, and seal the opening with a pinch of salt. Press the pills flat into a bowl, cover top and bottom, and seal the rim with clam powder mixed with vinegar. Further secure with damp paper strips. Then drive three iron nails into the ground to form a tripod, surround with charcoal fire, and cover the bowl with a *dǒu* of dry chaff. Do not fan the fire. By the next day, let cool and remove—the mercury will have congealed. Stew three black plums in three bowls of water, then pour the decoction over the elixir in an iron ladle until it turns white. Melt again in a sand crucible, pour into a mold, dust with wall dust, sprinkle with saltpeter, and return to the crucible. Pour the liquid to form the treasure.

**Method for the Mercury-Congealing Sand Elixir**
Mercury in any quantity, a small amount of *yínmǔ* (silver mother), *jìjiè* (schizonepeta), *qúmài* (dianthus), *huálú* (unknown), and red pepper. Grind these into a coarse powder and gradually add to a pan while stir-frying. When the herbs blacken, remove and discard them. Strain the remaining mixture through double-layered silk. Any untransformed residue should be processed again. For extraction, use *luógēn* (radish root) and one bowl of good vinegar, suspend in a silk bag, and stew in a bottle overnight. Then take a large *nánxīng* (arisaema), mix the mercury and silver powder with honey, place in a star-shaped mold, sprinkle with a small amount of *péngshā* (borax) and *yánghuā* (genkwa) powder on top, cover with more star powder, and seal the mouth with *huángdān* (lead oxide). Secure with toilet paper and clay, let dry, then nurture with *zǐmǔ* (mother-child) fire overnight. At dawn, refine with charcoal fire.

**Another Method**
One bowl of *zhāngliǔ* (unknown) juice and one *liǎng* of *fěnshuāng* (calomel). Wrap in silk and stew until the juice is exhausted. Use three *qián* of silver and one *liǎng* of powder to evenly coat. Place in a black bottle with three peppercorns at the bottom, pack the medicine tightly, then add four Sichuan peppercorns on top and seal. Bury the bottle in the ground, secure with *chìshízhī* (red halloysite), and seal all around with toilet paper and clay. Weigh down with a heavy object and refine with five *jīn* of charcoal fire.

**Another Method**
Grind three *qián* of *mǔ* (cinnabar) into powder, combine with seven *qián* of mercury to form cinnabar sand. Wrap in black paper and boil in Sichuan pepper decoction for three *shí* (six hours). Allow to cool, then bind tightly with raw honey. Use Sichuan pepper, *huánghuā* (yellow flower), *dìdīng* (Chinese violet), or *cǎowūtóu* (wild aconite) as powder—three ingredients in total—and wrap around the outer layer. Alternatively, mix equal parts of *nánxīng* (jack-in-the-pulpit), *wǔbèizǐ* (gallnut), *báiyǒu* (white lime), *báiqiān* (white swallow-wort), *dìjǐn* (Japanese creeper), or *cǎowūtóu* with raw honey to a thickness of half a finger, then wrap around the previous package. Seal the ball with salt-clay and refine with three *jīn* of fire.

**Method for Subduing Mercury Sand**
Place one *qián* of *mǔ* (cinnabar) and nine *qián* of mercury in a slow fire, using a small bowl. Sprinkle one *dàqián* (large coin’s worth) of powdered *gōngwūhuā* (unknown), *shéchuángzǐ* (cnidium seed), *chǔyè* (paper mulberry leaf), *wǔyèténg* (five-leaf vine), *lángdú* (wolfsbane), and *hànlián* (eclipta) onto the mercury. When smoke rises, stir with a bamboo stick until it turns the color of house dust, then remove the bowl. Discard the medicinal ash, pour the mercury onto paper, and let it congeal into hard cinnabar sand. If not fully formed, repeat the process. Once congealed, shape into a single piece, then grind *wǔbèizǐ* powder and *báiméi* (white plum) pulp into a paste in a mortar. Coat the cinnabar sand, wrap it in cotton (not too tightly), and bind with thread. Place in a *báihǔchí* (white tiger pool) bowl and stir-fry until the cotton turns scorched yellow. Remove and apply *guòguān* (passing-barrier) medicine: *tiānnánxīng* (jack-in-the-pulpit), *bànxià* (pinellia), *wǔwèizǐ* (schisandra), *báifùzǐ* (white aconite), *shǔkuíhuā* (hollyhock flower), and *wǔbèizǐ* as the outer barrier. Alternatively, mix *shǔkuíhuā* and *wǔbèizǐ* with honey, coat the exterior, wrap in toilet-clay, dry thoroughly, and refine with three *jīn* of fire until red.

**Method for Coating Mercury**
Place one *liǎng* of mercury in an oil-free pan, then lightly sprinkle *sānhuáng* (three yellows) powder over it. Use a chicken feather to evenly spread the *sānhuáng* powder across the mercury’s surface. Cover with a small dish, then seal the rim with a strip of damp paper to prevent air leakage. Place the pan in warm-and-cool ash fire. From *yín* (3–5 AM) to *mǎo* (5–7 AM), add warm-and-cool fire beneath the pan, keeping the ash fire at half-height. From *mǎo* to *chén* (7–9 AM), then *chén* to *sì* (9–11 AM), apply three *jīn* of strong fire to refine until glowing red. After a short while, remove and inspect: the dried mercury should resemble white alum, with golden flecks on the surface. Reheat in the furnace to remove blackness, then melt into an ingot. The resulting *nǚshí* (female stone) will be lustrous white when immersed in water. For larger batches, adjust the fire accordingly, following the same method. The above is transmitted by Master Liú Qì.

**Method for Congealing Mercury Sand into a Casket**
Grind five *liǎng* of mercury and half a *liǎng* of high-quality *báinǚshí* (white female stone) *xiàshuǐ* (water) into powder. Use a thick white bowl and a cast-iron pan. Place the mercury and *báinǚshí xiàshuǐ* in the pan, heat with warm-and-cool fire until the *xiàshuǐ* melts, then line the bowl with a piece of fine, well-scoured white silk. Pour the mixture into the bowl, and with your hands, gather the congealed portion. Wrap it in paper and hold it near the body to absorb warmth. Cover the residue with white alum, then nurture with a gentle fire for two seven-day periods. Use only three *liǎng* of charcoal fire daily for the first seven days, increasing to four *liǎng* thereafter—do not exceed this amount. After the second seven-day period, increase to five *liǎng* for the next four to five days. Once cooled, remove and refine in a crucible as usual. During the two seven-day nurturing periods, maintain a soft fire. This method is so secret that even father and son do not transmit it; if carelessly shared, ten generations will be left without hands or feet. Keep this formula on your person, and at the time of death, secretly entrust it to a close relative. After passing, have the cinnabar casket cast into a long-flowing river—do not let it fall into the wrong hands. Perform this process no more than twice a month; do not overdo it. Beware, beware.

**Master Gé’s *Purple Empyrean Elixir Canon* Method**
**Method for Subduing Fire with Sulfur**
Obtain one *jīn* of sulfur from a foreign ship or monk’s robe. Grind it to powder and spread evenly in a flat-bottomed pan. Use rain-soaked mulberry branch ash lye—clarified and strong—for best results. Pour three *dǒu* of the lye over the sulfur to a depth of two fingers, then boil for one *fúshí* (twelve hours), stirring frequently to ensure evenness. Test a small amount over fire: if it subdues without igniting, it is ready; if not, add more lye and continue boiling until subdued. The sulfur should turn black as lacquer. Melt in a crucible with three to five *jīn* of charcoal fire, then pour into molds to form ingots. Later, crush, wash, dry, and grind into powder. Refine and cast into vessels, or use for medicinal purposes.

**Master Sūn’s *Elixir Canon* Method for Subduing Sulfur**
Grind one *liǎng* of sulfur, one *liǎng* of saltpeter, and half a *liǎng* of *lúshā* (sal ammoniac) into powder. Melt in a crucible, then pour into a mold to subdue.

**Huáng Sānguān’s Method for Subduing Sulfur**
Take four *liǎng* each of sulfur, *tānshí* (alumstone), and white alum. Mix half a bowl of fresh ginger juice with half a bowl of whetstone water, then soak five *dìng* of *zàojiǎo* (Chinese honey locust) to extract half a bowl of juice. Dissolve the three ingredients in this liquid until it reaches a thin consistency. Heat in an iron vessel over fire until dry, then scrape the powder into a casket and nurture for three seven-day periods.

**Method for Subduing Fire with Sulfur**
Grind two *liǎng* each of sulfur and saltpeter. Place the ingredients in a silver-melting pot or clay jar, then dig a pit in the ground and set the vessel inside, level with the surface. Pack soil tightly around it. Burn three undamaged *zàojiǎo* seeds until charred, then drop them in one by one. When the flames subside, place three *jīn* of raw and cooked charcoal around the mouth and refine.

When one-third of the charcoal has burned away, remove the remaining fire and do not allow it to cool before retrieval—thus is the fire subdued.

**Master Ge’s Alchemical Canon: Method for Subduing Realgar**
On the seventh day of the seventh lunar month, gather mulberry leaves in any quantity and dry them in the shade. For every *liǎng* of powdered mulberry leaves, add one *liǎng* of realgar. Place them in a ceramic vessel, layering mulberry leaves on top and bottom with realgar in the center, then seal tightly. Refine with ten *jīn* of honey and charcoal fire until stabilized. To convert it into powder, proceed in the same manner. For medicinal use, melt one *liǎng* of yellow wax with seven *gāngzǐ* (croton seeds), grind into a ball, and coat with one *liǎng* of mercury. Secure it to the navel with an adhesive; itching will occur within a day or two. After six years, the mercury hardens and becomes unusable.

**Great Void Alchemical Canon: Method for Subduing Realgar**
Grind realgar into fine powder. Mix with refined honey to the consistency of edible maltose, wrap tightly in several layers of coarse paper, and bind securely with silk thread. Boil a pot of water until rolling, then suspend the packet inside without touching the bottom. Continuously add boiling water to prevent cooling; use approximately one *yán* of water. Remove and grind in an iron mortar until extremely fine. Form into millet-sized pills with glutinous rice porridge water, and take one pill on an empty stomach with warm wine.

**Master Ge’s Alchemical Canon: Method for Subduing Orpiment**
Use orpiment in any quantity, layering subdued sal ammoniac on the bottom and top. Add borax the size of a *zàojiǎo* seed; for every *liǎng* of lead, it will be complete.

**Master Sun’s Alchemical Canon: Method for Subduing Fire in Orpiment**
Take half a *liǎng* of leaf orpiment and two *liǎng* of sal ammoniac, grind into fine powder. Mix evenly with egg white, fill into an eggshell, and seal the opening with paper. Then, grind one *liǎng* of white alum into powder, mix with egg white, and coat the shell; dry over fire. Next, grind one *liǎng* of saltpeter into fine powder, mix with egg white, and coat the shell; dry again. Finally, place one *jīn* of red lead in a vessel, set the orpiment and sal ammoniac inside, cover with red lead to form a casket, and seal with salt-clay. Dry, then refine with half a *chèng* of charcoal fire. Remove when complete. To use, melt cinnabar and mercury into a liquid, add one pill of the medicine, and form into water-chestnut-sized pills with yellow wax.

**Methods for Subduing the Eight Minerals**

**Master Ge’s Alchemical Canon: Method for Subduing Chalcanthite**
Take one *liǎng* of chalcanthite and four *liǎng* of subdued sal ammoniac. Place in a sealed vessel and refine with three *jīn* of charcoal fire until red-hot. Use charcoal to form a pit, place the chalcanthite in the center, cover with sal ammoniac, and encase in a salt casket. Alternatively, nurture for one day before refining with three *jīn* of fire.

**Master Sun’s Alchemical Canon: Method for Subduing Chalcanthite**
Grind equal parts chalcanthite and green alum into powder, then refine with intense fire until molten.

**Method for Dead Chalcanthite**
Extract juice from hibiscus leaves and boil dry in a bowl with fresh ginger juice. Use a pot previously fumigated with a piece of frankincense, wrap the chalcanthite in paper, place it inside, and refine until molten. Pour onto a hot iron plate; the chalcanthite is thus rendered inert.

**Method for Subduing Arsenic**
Grind saltpeter and white alum into fine powder, layering them on the bottom and top. Place arsenic in the center within a crucible, seal with *báihǔfěng* (white tiger powder), and refine until red-hot. Remove and cast into ingots.

**Method for Dead Arsenic**
Take three *liǎng* of arsenic, six *qián* of cinnabar, six *qián* of *fěnshuāng* (calomel), and any quantity of saltpeter and alum to fill a vessel. Use a ceramic container, first lining the bottom with half a layer of saltpeter, then placing three *liǎng* of arsenic inside. Cover with half the remaining medicine, then layer alum, and finally fill the vessel with saltpeter. Seal with salt-clay, bind with hemp fibers, and seal again with salt-clay. Once dry, place in a casket and refine daily with one *jīn* of fire for three days. When removed, it will appear frosty white—thus is the arsenic rendered inert.

**Method for Subduing Arsenolite (Tai Shang’s White Ying Elixir)**
Grind half a *liǎng* of saltpeter and one *liǎng* of arsenolite into fine powder. Place in an oiled ceramic jar and stir-fry, adding two *liǎng* of white ash powder. Refine with four *jīn* of charcoal fire until the ash cools. Remove; it will be as white as snow. For every three *qián* of this powder, add two *qián* of white wax, mix with water, and form into millet-sized pills. Take one pill with freshly drawn water to treat malaria and dysentery.

**Great Void Alchemical Canon: Method for Subduing Sulfur**
Grind two *liǎng* of sulfur, two *liǎng* of saltpeter, and three *qián* of sal ammoniac into fine powder. Place in a large ingot pot and sprinkle with *fēnghuà báihǔ* (weathered white tiger powder) to fill the vessel without pressing down. Mix oyster shell powder with vinegar and coat the pot to a thickness of two fingers. Place the pot on the ground, arrange charcoal around it at a distance of four fingers, stacking it one *chǐ* high. Ignite three *jīn* of fire from the top, reducing to two *jīn* as it burns. When cool, retrieve the arsenolite from the center, which will resemble jade. Soak in fine water, then form into millet-sized pills with steamed cake. Take one pill on an empty stomach with cold water. It may be incorporated into various medicines and is particularly effective for treating deep-seated cold and hernia in men and women. For transmutation, its effects are extraordinary.

**Method for Subduing Jade-like Arsenolite**
True *shínǎoyóu* (naphtha) will spread upon contact with hair, curl upon touching the tongue, and not stain clothing. Grind four *liǎng* of jade-colored arsenolite into fine powder, mix with one *liǎng* of naphtha and one *liǎng* of fresh ginger juice, and blend evenly with the arsenolite powder to form a stiff dough. Place in a small ceramic vessel, first coating the interior with ginger juice. Do not cover; instead, expose the opening and apply gentle heat from all sides to eliminate yin qi. Once dry, remove and grind again.

Again mix with ginger juice to a dough-like consistency, return to the vessel, and apply gentle heat until dry. Repeat this process five times, then grind evenly with one *liǎng* of fine saltpeter. Next, take an unworked iron crucible with a three-*shēng* capacity, boil one *liǎng* of fresh ginger and yellow earth within it. Sift the earth to a fine, moist consistency, and pack it firmly to just below the crucible’s rim. Carve a depression in the earth, about one *cùn* from the crucible’s edge. Within this depression, fill and pack *fēnghuà* (weathered) fine white tiger powder to the brim. At the center of the white tiger powder, carve a small depression and embed the arsenolite vessel within, packing it firmly. Cover it again with white tiger powder. Then, take one *jīn* of walnut meat, break into small pieces, and arrange atop the white tiger powder. Seal the crucible’s rim with a mixture of yellow earth, paper fiber, and mud, then invert a ceramic bowl over the opening, ensuring a tight seal. Coat the entire exterior of the crucible with salt-clay to a thickness of half a finger, extending downward to just below the rim, and dry over heat. Fill the bowl with eight parts of fermented water. Place the crucible on a dry patch of ground atop a three-legged stand, and apply five *jīn* of fire until the crucible glows red throughout. Cease heating and allow it to cool naturally. Upon opening, the arsenolite will have fused into a single mass, clear as crystal, luminous in sunlight—a supreme elixir for the five metals and a master key for the eight minerals. All methods under heaven emerge from this single furnace, its wonders beyond compare. Guard this secret, guard it well.

**Method for Subduing Sal Ammoniac from the Alchemical Classic of Immortal Ge**

**Method for Subduing Sal Ammoniac with Pomegranate:**
Take two *liǎng* of sal ammoniac, boil it in the juice of sour pomegranate pulp and seeds until reduced by half, then use again. Burn the residue to ash, leach with water, and evaporate to frost. Scrape into a lidded vessel, seal tightly, and calcine with fire to subdue it. During boiling, add five *liǎng* of powdered *wǔyècǎo* (a herb with long, angular leaves resembling water caltrop, its stems bearing purple markings; abundant in western Sichuan). If unavailable, use pomegranate leaves alone, boiled in wood-ash lye within a ceramic vessel. After two subduing cycles, dry it, scrape into a lidded vessel, seal tightly, and dry thoroughly to expel all yin *qi*. Calcine with seven *jīn* of fire, then remove when cool.

**Method for Subduing Sal Ammoniac:**
Line the bottom and cover the top with saltpeter, seal with mud, and burn to subdue the fire. After boiling the sal ammoniac in ash lye, nourish it with *chǔ* leaves and silkworm droppings over fire, then dissolve in hot water, leach, and calcine until red—this yields an even finer result.

**Method for Subduing Fire in Sal Ammoniac:**
Take one *liǎng* of sal ammoniac, and half a *liǎng* each of oyster shell, cuttlebone, and clamshell (if any ingredient is lacking, substitute with subdued alum). Grind all into fine powder, heat a crucible until glowing red, and gradually add the mixture. Once subdued to ash, remove, grind again, and leach the liquid into a ceramic vessel. When nearly dry, transfer to a crucible, heat until molten, and it will resemble snow.

**Method for Subduing Fire in Sal Ammoniac:**
Take one *liǎng* of sal ammoniac and one *liǎng* of cuttlebone, grind together, and heat a crucible until red-hot. Melt the mixture into a liquid, remove, and cool. Grind finely, steep in boiling water, leach the liquid, and evaporate to frost. Re-calcine. Use powdered *chǔ* seeds and late silkworm droppings: first line half the powder in a crucible, tamp firmly, then place two layers of black paper. Add the sal ammoniac, cover with two more layers of black paper, and top with the remaining powder, tamped firmly. Do not seal tightly. Calcine with four *jīn* of fire until exhausted, then remove when cool—the fire will be subdued.

**Method for Subduing Alum from the Alchemical Classic of Immortal Ge:**
Take one *liǎng* of fine white alum, crush into pieces the size of soap beans. Use five *liǎng* of *dìjǐncǎo* (if unavailable, substitute with selfheal). Mix with yellow clay, paper fiber, and mud to a proper consistency. Seal a well-oiled ceramic vessel capable of holding the mixture with this mud, about half a *cùn* thick. When dry, place a half-brick on the ground, further sealing the base and sides. Gradually heat with charcoal until the mixture melts into a liquid, stir evenly with a willow branch, and continue for the time it takes to brew one or two cups of tea. Then gradually withdraw the fire and allow to cool. Break the vessel to retrieve the powder. Line the top and bottom with two *liǎng* of tung seeds, evenly distributed, with cinnabar in between, filling the vessel completely. Seal the seams with red halloysite and mud, securing with two iron rods in a cross. Use three *liǎng* of talc, two *liǎng* of charcoal, a small amount of white clay, and saltwater-soaked paper mud to seal the lidded vessel. Dry in a pit, then nourish with half a *jīn* of fire for twenty-one days. Later, add another half *jīn* of fire and nourish for forty-nine days. Once the cycle is complete, grind into powder and form into mung-bean-sized pills with glutinous rice porridge. One pill will transmute one *liǎng* of mercury into treasure.

**Method for Refining Bronze:**
Take equal parts of powdered chalcanthite, melanterite, and green vitriol. Beat refined copper into thin sheets, mix the powdered ingredients with vinegar to a paste-like consistency, and apply to the copper. Seal with powdered red halloysite mixed with cow dung, dry in the shade, and heat with gentle and strong fire for three cycles. Then place in a crucible, melt into a liquid, and it will become a precious metal of fine quality.

**Method for the Longevity Vault:**
Take a porcelain vessel from Dingzhou and seal it with Six-One Mud. Use one *liǎng* each of raw mercury and cinnabar, and one *liǎng* of raw silver powder. First place the mercury, then layer the cinnabar to press the mercury, alternating with silver powder until all is used. Seal tightly, then place in a small furnace. Arrange charcoal of sorghum-stalk length around the vessel, one *liǎng* of fire on each of the four sides, forming four pillars of charcoal. Nourish for seven days and nights. When the time is complete, calcine with one *jīn* of fire. Remove the contents, place back into the vessel, and add two *liǎng* of raw mercury. Repeat the charcoal arrangement and nourish for seven days. Add another two *liǎng* of mercury as before, nourish for seven days, then retrieve and refine into treasure. Add two *liǎng* of mercury again, completing the seven-day fire cycle. By repeatedly adding two *liǎng* of mercury, the process becomes everlasting.
